												As someone who loved GSB 1 I just can't get behind this game.  The biggest problem I have with this game is the lack of modules/ships/races.  I had unlocked everything after the first few normal missions, and there just isn't much.  Unlike GSB 1, where there wasn't much in terms of ship class specialization, GSB 2 is all about specializing what a ship can do based on its size.  This means that each ship size only has a few different weapons/modules, and they all basically do the same thing.  Dreadnaughts, for example, have a handful of different laser and missle weapons they can use.  But the range is the same on just about every component, and the damage is very similar.  Ultimately your choice comes down to "fire slightly faster or hit slightly harder".  There also isn't really a good point defense option in the game either, but that doesn't really matter because missles are just basically slow beam weapons - they lack the range or damage or GSB 1 missles weapons.Like I said, GSB 2 predicates the game on specializing ships based on size.  Dreadnaughts are *supposed* to have a hard time killing fighters, which are supposed to be good at killing dreadnaughts, for example.  The idea behind this is you need a mix of fighters/destroyers/dreadnaughts to have a viable fleet.  In practice this specialization doesn't work.  Fighters can't damage dreadnaught shields or armor, and dreadnaughts have access to tractor beams which allow them to kill fighters.  Destroyers meanwhile, which are supposed to be the anti-fighter ship, arn't amazing at killing fighters because destroyers are quite fragile and, unlike dreadnaughts, fighters actually can kill destroyers quite quickly.  The AI is kind of stupid and ignores destroyers with its fighters, but that doesn't fix the underlying problem.  Ultimately, I found that a fleet composed of dreadnaughts, each of which had two tractor beams, could easily beat all of the normal and hard missions in the game.  The absolute lack of components makes this a very boring strategy, as just about every ship of a given class is going to look almost identical to any other ship of that class regardless of how you try to build it.I was also dissapointed with the other races.  The game ships with 4, the basic terran race you get at the start and the 3 other races that you have more than enough points to unlock after the tutorial mission (along with just about every component, seriously I know I said this before but I think I had unlocked literally everything by mission 4).  I don't get what the benefit of the other races over the terran race is.  They all appear to be the same - focused very heavily on armor with 1 or 2 exclusive components that arn't really any different from the basic components.  One thing I really liked about GSB 1 was that the races were quite distinct, but GSB 2 is just really lacking in that area.  All in all, the game is dissapointing.  I see what they were going for design wise - trying to force you to make more complicated fleet and ship designs by hyper specializing each ship class.  However, their implementation of that fell flat on its face and, in practice, all it has led to is a very simplified, very boring version of GSB 1.

A gratuitous sequel or a gratuitously tough act to follow?Gratuitous Space Battles was always going to be a tricky one to follow, it was lightning in a bottle, a game where you sat back and enjoyed a cold or hot drink as fleets you carefully designed smashed into each other for your entertainment. It had the benefit of many years of polish, expansion, and even a full on 4X-lite mode which allowed you to involve yourself and lose yourself in a campaign based around those massive, wonderful battles. It's a game with a very unique premise and therefore making a sequel was always going to be a harsh one to follow up, because whatever was made, it was going to always be held up to not the "initial release" of GSB, which barely anyone remembers, but the final, expansion laden version, which has so much more added to it. Extra races, game modes, everything.When the first game was so riveting, how do you go about improving the proverbial bicycle?So we come to the second iteration of Gratuitous Space Battles. It's called GSB 2 but frankly I'm going to look at it from a different angle and call it Gratuitous Space Battles "Version 2". What -should- have happened (and Cliffy is going to hate me for posting this) is that existing purchasers should have got an upgrade discount, a significant one, as a way of thanking them for their support and encouraging them to buy in to the new version of GSB. Financially it would not have been perhaps the best option, it's hard to say, but it would have been the most palatable option for the fans and would almost have certainly disarmed most of the initial complaints.It's important to understand that this is functionally GSB but effectively rebuilt from the ground up, it has a new combat engine with additional classes of ship, a much, much more powerful graphics engine which means that the combat in space looks orders of magnitude more pretty (this is something of a double edged sword for some). However, much like the initial release, it only has the basics behind it, the initial set of challenges, the initial races and building blocks for you to get creative with. The blocks are good, the graphics and layout is a major step up though, but it's very, very much GSB1 upgraded, and there's no escaping that fact.More no doubt is planned and will be added (indeed, custom battles are in, and more tools are being added into the ship creator screen), and Cliffy almost certainly will add a full fat singleplayer mode of some description (though it's unlikely to be an open ended 4X this time). But once again, we're back to GSB "Version 2.0" as opposed to say "2.7.x" with all the expansions and patches and balancing.So there is good news on the horizon, yes?Yes. I expect so, if previous games are anything to go by, this game will see a lot of post-release support, and a lot of extensions which will flesh out the game, solve the balancing, and over time refine a lot of the rough edges. Once the content is in and there's more meat on the bones, and the weapons are more balanced so they have their respective roles (along with the new ship classes), this will without doubt exceed GSB "Version 1", even with its' many expansions.But claiming it's a sequel and not an upgrade of the original is probably the mistake that's been made, even if it's a perceptive one, this is very much the new version, and it should have been treated as "Gratuitous Space Battles 2.0" and not a sequel. It's not, it's the GSB we all know and love, but it's had the work done to it that makes it worthy of a major revision change, and a major update fee for people who were on the 1.x branch. People who hadn't bought in should still be paying in sum, the full price and deservedly so, GSB remains a brilliant, wonderful gem of a game, one that hasn't aged much (and with GSB2, it has the potential to remain current for an awful lot longer), but perhaps this was one of those occasions where a bit more care for the existing customerbase would have paid off in the long run.A tough place to be for an indie dev.I respect the need for Indie Devs to put food on the plate, but I also know the market, I've spent most of the last decade watching, analysing and monitoring the market as it's shifted, like dunes of sand across the desert. As good as the game is, it's not a sequel, it's the new version of GSB, it's -good- for what it is, but it's still very much in it's infancy, and therefore at least until the rough edges have been sanded off, you may want to wait just a little longer. As much as it pains me to stand against Cliffy, because I've been one of his more positive supporters over time, I feel this time he misjudged the launch and the initial rollout. Nothing unfixable, but for now I'd suggest giving this game more time to mature.Update : Post release, where's the gravy?The game has been out now for quite some time, and this still remains a bitter pill for me to swallow, having been, and remaining a supporter of Positech's work. GSB2 has been a commercial misfire. The campaign as it is, is lackluster, and despite my repeated attempts to get a proper campaign structure put in, there was little interest in my suggestions. So what we have now is something that's barely functional and only adequate. There's STILL no significant post release content, even though there's been plenty of patch work and tweaking of balance (which still remains a bugbear, perhaps owing to the additional complexity of the game now with the additional ship classes and so on).I still believe it should be one to watch, and perhaps purchase at deep discount. But I cannot recommend this at full price as it stands. There's not enough here compared to it's infinitely richer predecessor, and prettier graphics alone don't cut it. Had Cliffy actually implemented a campaign worth a damn, then things might be a bit more promising, but right now? No dice. It seems right now his focus is on Democracy 3, which is probably for the best, as that is far more successful.Verdict : Wishlist it, and wait for a steep discount.Updated 4/10/15

												Gratuitous Space Battles 2 is a great concept for a game. I've never played GSB, so I can not compare the two.However, GSB2 is not a finished game (though it seems to have been released as such). Here is a short list of stuff that sort of points towards a beta:  - crashes every 30-60 minutes (version 1.28 which presumably fixed lots of crashes)  - occasionally has missing textures (you see white boxes in place of enemy ships or the battle map)  - UI is a complete mess  - eye candy takes up a lot of screen space while important info is very small)  - takes a lot of clicking and remembering to see which planets I've done on which difficulties for how much honor  - UI elements block stuff you need to manipulate (on planet selection, when setting ship orders, etc)  - it's hard to tell what is relevant information and what is not based on screen layouts  - forgetting to close a dialog box prevents you from doing anything else (could just auto close the dialog)  - balance seems to be off for all kinds of things, including prices, race/ship/module differences, etc.  - online high score tables already have ridiculous top results  - occasionally the AI wants to go huddle in a corner "attacking"  - there is little reason to try to improve your score other than personal ambition  - only eleven missions (nine of which are available on three difficulty levels)  - battles became a lot more fun to watch once I disabled most of the "extra fluff" like asteroids, bloom, etc. from themI've had fun playing it, and I still want to play more, but my motivation is fading fast due to constantly having to fight game issues that should not be there.There is certainly value in there, but at it's current state (version 1.28) I can not recommend it, even though I've found it fun to play. Wait for a sale, wait for 3-5 patches, or just jump recklessly in. :)

												I want to recommend this game, but sadly I can't. The gameplay has potential, but it's unbalanced, it favors a stupid strategy, and once you figure out your special fleet, it will beat all 10 levels, of which is basically the whole game. For $25, I spent about $2.50 per hour I paid, and you can find plenty of games where you'll get much more gameplay for your buck.It's got a ton of potential. It's super fun to design ships, use your energy/crew economy and try to figure out the most balanced and effective fleet to crush an opponent. But once you figure out the game, how the parts work, and spend a little time designing a really good ship, you'll beat the whole short game.I had a ton of fun at first. Then I realized that I could just create a fleet of my strongest ship and crush all the levels they have, and there are not many levels at all. You can fight in about 10 different scenarios, with a normal/hard/extreme difficulty, but once you made your special fleet, you can pretty much crush any of them. For me, that was just putting as many of my dreadnought class ships as I could. They had just a few anti-fighter (small ship) weapons, and tons of one type of missile. It destroyed everything on almost every map.And once you figure that one out, you can just rack up "Honor" which is used to unlock new parts, but they're not going to change the game too much.I want the game to be more balanced. I want to have to build a balanced fleet with specialized ships that heal my ships, special dog-fighters, destroyers that counter their destroyers, but it doesn't matter. All I need is my one dreadnought with all the missiles and it'll crush anything large or small.So, IMO, this game is a waste of money. It needs some massive changes for it to actually fulfill it's potential, and I don't think they're going to spend their time and change it that drastically. If your dreadnoughts can take care of all the little guys because their armor is too high to take any damage from them, why bother building small guys that won't be able to destroy their dreadnoughts? Just have more dreadnoughts than the enemy and you win.It's really too bad, because I was having a ton of fun until I figured that cheap move out. And either way, there's only about 10 levels to beat, and multiplayer consists of creating a fleet and letting people download it and fight it. It really doesn't add that much replayability.

												Preface: GSB filled a very unique niche for me, and I appreciate the original for what it is.  I have literally grown up with video games, and I am critical of them because they are important to me.  I like this franchise.  Keep that in mind.GSB2 is immediately something of a letdown.  The first --UNQUESTIONABLE FIRST-- thing any sequel should ALWAYS be doing is refining its UI.  GSB suffered from a horribly primitive UI wherein the mouse hand performed 99% of the interaction.  Ten fingers plus only one point of input=a very inelegant interface.  A game with as many sliders, locations, and items to interact with on a constant basis as GSB absolutely DEMANDS a more fluid control scheme.GSB2, above all else, has not remedied the problems of the first game.  Aside from the formation shortcut shift+F (the only one I use on an absolutely constant basis) there are far too many inputs and interactions in dire need of shortcut buttons, hotkeys and less intervening mouse clicks to get things done.  There are so many forced, unneeded clicks to jump around that just moving from one screen to the one you want feels tedious.  The series of actions needed to navigate the menu are unbelievably clunky; I counted having to hit the 'main menu' button FOUR TIMES CONSECUTIVELY to get to the actual main menu from some screens. 												GSB2 improves upon nearly everything from GSB1.  If you're like me and you like watching some pew-pew and some boom-boom in space, you'll like Gratuitous Space Battles 2.  GSB2 is about the spectacle of watching fleets of spaceships blow each other up.  It is the best part of any sci-fi movie, turned into a game.That being said, I will now qualify my recommendation and address complaints I've seen others make.  While I do think GSB2 improves upon nearly everything from GSB1, it doesn't really CHANGE a whole lot.  Nothing is really new or revolutionary to the design, although almost everything is a step up.  And the complaints others have made about about crashing, or what feels like a lack of content, are legitimate, although it has more content than GSB1.  Like I said, there isn't a lot of NEW stuff, although basically everything has been improved.GSB2 is a much prettier game than 1, with better lighting, better looking explosions, better looking ships, customizable ship appearances, and better looking debris and backgrounds.  I did turn off asteroids because, while they look cool, they were ultimately distracting.  Because there are a lot more layers of things happening (debris, ships, asteroids, clouds, etc.) it can be difficult to understand the action at times, especially when you have the wreckage of dozens of ships slowly floating across your screen.  While everything has more detail, GSB1 looked cleaner, if that makes sense.GSB2 seems more balanced than 1.  I'm writing this review after having played all the way through the missions that come with the game, and I beat them all on normal.  Combined arms are now much more important.  Whereas in GSB1 I basically never used destroyers, they have now become an important part of every fleet, because fighters are now harder to deploy.  Fighters in GSB1 were OP; you could deploy as many of them as you wanted, limited only by pilot availability, and simply use them to overwhelm larger and more powerful fleets.  Now fighters have fuel, which limits their deployment time before they have to refuel, and they have to be assigned to a "carrier" (cruiser or dreadnought with appropriate module) and carriers have limited hangar space.  Overall I found fleet composition to be more challenging and thoughtful experience.Even in the few hours I've played, I have experienced a handful of crashes.  While the crashes were annoying, no progress was ever lost, and I was able to get back to where I was within seconds.  The game loads fast.  I think complaints about the crashing are COMPLETELY legitimate, but overall the crashing didn't detract from my experience.  I also experienced a saved fleet not being available to load.  It only effected me one time, because there was only one time I wanted to recycle my fleet composition and disposition, but it is still a problem (albiet one that didn't bother me too much).The one complaint I've seen that I don't quite understand are the complaints about a lack of campaign or strategic layer.  I mean I understand that people would like something like that... but... I mean it IS called GRATUITOUS Space Battles for a reason.  This game is about building fleets and watching them explode.  It delivers.GSB2 isn't a game I'm going to sit down a put 20 hours into all in one sitting, but it is a game I'll come back to from time to time over the next couple of years, just to fiddle around with ship designs, and to watch waves of missles smash their way through formations of spaceships.If you've never played GSB1, then this is a great place to get started as it offers the same joys as the first one, but more interesting challenges.  If you loved GSB1, as I did, I think GSB 2 offers plenty to like.

												**UPDATE** on review:  Up to ver.1.39 as of 8/7/15 and I've not crashed in a long time.  Those folks who had issues, should revisit the game.  The latest tweaks are mostly graphical re: shields.  I am updating this review to let people know the developer has consistently worked to fix bugs and add tweaks and even content, since the release.  If you were on the fence about this game, or you were initially disappointed with glitches, play the updated game with a fresh outlook and I think you be pleasantly pleased.--------This is not just a redo of GSB1.  The game improves the graphics and the game play is similar to the original in that you design each of your ships, select and put together your perfect combination of those ships, give each ship orders for battle contigencies and then watch it unfold!   Formations of ships, placement and orders given, all play a role in what happens in the battles.  That part is the same and even better than the original!!!  GSB 2 adds new ship categories including gunships, destroyers (support ships) and Dreadnaughts (aka: battleships).  The Dreadnaughts can also be outfitted to be carriers as well.  It all depends on your designs.  This is where GSB 2 really shines!  You can modify all defensive and offensive aspects as well as engines, crew cabins, targeting enhancements, etc.  Once you decide on your ship's functional pieces and parts, you can design the asthetic pieces by adding various wings, structures, vents, engines, antennae, and so much more!  Pick the color of your ship and/or each individual part.  You can add spinning, blinking, and glowing parts to your ships.  So MANY choices! --The possibilities are nearly endless.  The battle modes are fun with 3 different levels of difficulty.  If that is not enough action for you, then try my favorite part, the "CHALLENGES"!  Face other players' fleets in asynchronous battles online.   The extra Steam workshop features push this game over the top.  If you are new to this, then the workshop can help you even more, being able to see what others are doing with their ships, etc.  I have spent many hours on the 1st game, the beta of this one, and will spend MANY more hours (much to the chagrin of my wife)  on this one!  This is NOT an arcade-style ACTION game.   It is not a 4X game.   It is an intellectual, planning and creative game that will provide hours of enjoyment as you try to build a better fleet than the game's or other players on the internet!

Please note that I recommend this game mostly because I got it on sale for -75% off, at $3.75.TLDR: Well worth what I paid, get it on sale under $5 if you can.+ Graphics are beautiful.+ Battles are fun to watch and sometimes even exciting to see your ships barely pull through.+ Ship visual customization is wonderful, not quite on the level of SPORE but close.+ Online challenge matches (made by players) make for endless possibilities.- Weapons have very little difference, there are obvious bests.- Not enough different anomolies, there needs to be one that prevents use of missiles.- Frigates and fighters are rather useless and that shouldn't be the case.- Not nearly enough uniqueness between the races and different ship hulls of the same class.I enjoyed GSB1 and I also enjoyed this one.  I like the funny random ship named, I like the chatter during combat, I enjoy the minor amount of strategy involved.  I loved the updated graphics, the explosions are pretty.What I don't enjoy are the ship modules.  There's really only a few of them worth using and there are obvious bests and not really any strategy to making a good ship unless you run into a problem where there's an anomoly that prevents you from using one of the components you're using.  Multi warhead missiles is the only weapon you ever need which is ridiculous, a nuke if you feel like it, tons of armor, repairs, no shields are EVER needed and rarely useful.  You never really need engines either which is uh.. a bit unrealistic but whatever.  Engines shouldn't even be a module, they should just come on the ship.  There's one map that doesn't allow repair modules... that's the only one I had to make a new ship for really after my basic dread/cruiser/destroyer setups were made.On the note of ships all you really need to obliterate almost any map is a few dreads with tons of armor and repair systems and a few combat tractor beams to take out fighters.  Now there is one map where the enemy has a TON of fighters and this didn't work too well but other than that..  There's no point in frigates, none.  Fighters and Gunships (bigger fighters) are also completely unnecessary which is ridiculous and you only really need cruisers if you can't use dreads at that system and you build them just the same as you would a dread.I got about 9 hours out of the game before I had defeated every single battle map on normal, replayed a few several times over to see how little I could defeat it with and played through one shot of the "campaign" as they call it... which is a joke really because it's just like 6 battles in a row with the ships you set up for the first one. (minus any that die along the way)  A good bit of that time was spent designing ships (visually) as well which was fun, definitely a nice touch to the game.So in closing I'll say this.  It was well worth the money I paid for it, it's a beautiful game visually compared to the first and I did get a good amount of fun out of it for the money I spent.  This said there is some serious room for work here, the game feels unfinished in some ways.  I also had a lot of crashes on loading screens which thankfully only set me back like 10 seconds a piece at most.  If it crashed during combat or fleet setup or ship customization that would really suck but it didn't so I can't say the crashes were that bad.

												I loved GSB 1. I want to love GSB 2.Unfortunately GSB 2 is not what it should have been or could have been. 1. For a start, the game itself feels less polished than when GSB 1 was first released. It's hard to discern what's going on in battle and it's more of a cluttered mess than the first game. I can only play the first two battlefields and even then only if I don't put too many units in. In larger scale engagements, the game will just crash mid-battle. Oh and if I lose (even on the small maps), the game freezes and I can't even use Task manager to shut it down. I have to log off from the Ctrl-Alt-Delete screen.3. Virtually no racial distinction. They feel like slight variations of the same ships. In GSB 1, choosing a race made a significant difference to the way the game was played and yet in GSB 2, all that really matters is your choice of fitting. The hull itself, and by extension the race, makes almost no difference. The only good feature at the moment is the visual customization... and that doesn't redeem the game. In its current state, for me at least, it's completely unplayable. For now I recommend not buying this game; it shouldn't have been released until it was ready.

While I think that the twenty dollar price tag is a bit steep for most people, this game is very much worth the money if you wait for it to go on sale. Every fight is a puzzle, and many have unique gimmicks in the form of anomalies. In one battle, the enemy may have a lot of fighters and bombers, so destroyers with tractor beams and anti-fighter lasers are key. In the next battle, tractor beams don't work because of a technobablon particle flux wave, or whatever, so you need to plan accordingly. You can make your own puzzles too, with challenges and custom battles (also a little buggy).Buy this game. It's a great game, and knowing Mr. Harris, he's got DLC and expansion packs coming to make it even better. EDIT (No he does not, sadly)

												So I came across a bug in GSB2.  I've noticed a few other minor ones before this, small graphics glitches, ship designs which temporarily disappeared, and such; But nothing which actually prevented me from playing.  Until this morning. I was trying to beat one of the latter scenarios using only frigates or lighter ships.  A futile mission perhaps, but that's partly the appeal of the game.  Setting a goal and then trying to beat it with the absolute minimum expenditure of resources.  This lead to me creating a huge formation of frigates, which seems to have exceeded the maximum that the game would allow.  This caused the game to crash whenever I’d try to start the scenario. I’ve been in this situation before. You submit a bug report and then maybe get a canned email response saying that the problem will be looked into, and then nothing further . You wait months and just hope that there will be a fix in the next patch.  Hell, you often just hope that there will BE a next patch. So how long do you think it took Positech to get this resolved?  About 10 minutes. I got a personal response straight from Cliff (the one-man developer of GSB2), got a workaround to the problem and assurance that it’d be fixed in the next patch. That’s a huge indication that this is someone who really cares about their games and will work to make ‘em great.Unfortunately this experience has left me in an existential crisis and has potentially revealed a serious flaw in my psychological makeup. Years of internet immersion has honed my sarcastic wit to razor sharp perfection.  I can be a snarky♥♥♥♥♥hole at the drop of a hat, spewing smarm and vitriol at anybody who dares to not be perfect on the internet, all from the comfort and anonymity of my bedroom.  And I like to think I’m quite a bit better at it than most.  But now I find that I need to praise something. To be positive and supportive. My every instinct recoils at the notion.But why should it.  I really like the game. Judging from his lineup of games, Cliff seems to have very similar tastes to my own. Games that don’t rely on twitch skills, but on planning and strategy.  Games where you can constantly tweak a bunch of individual small aspects to see how they affect the system as a whole. And that’s what GSB2 is. If you think that just completing each of the missions is the goal, you can achieve that fairly quickly and with little planning.  Just throw more ships at the problem and eventually you’ll win.  But the real challenge is trying to do it with as little as possible.  I usually start by making a fleet which can win the engagement fairly decisively, and then start whittling it down and tweaking stuff until I think I’ve got it down to the bare minimum. Eventually I get to where I’m sure it’s just not possible to do it with anything less.  Then I check the high scores and see that not only do I not have the best score ever, I’m about 50,000 points shy of it.  Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ I’ve got to rethink this whole strategy. This is how this game eats up hours of my life.  And it’s time well spent as far as I’m concerned.

Game-playGratuitous Space Battles is back again, and this sequel is a dream come true to players who enjoyed the first game.Being famous for its vast customization and allowing the players to exert their creativity, this time, even more customization is allowed.Being able to color and re-size the vast amount of parts and modules to mount on different ship hulls sizes and more-specialized-hulls for the construction of your space-crafts, provided great complexity and possibilities for you to spend hours just to construct your own unique ship.With mods being available and sharing of spacecraft design through steam, there is no limit to the content of this game. This game features the standard mission game mode, which the player will need to defeat a group of preset enemy space-crafts. The less total cost of your space-crafts deployed to tackle the mission, the more honor points you will get in-return for you to unlock more modules, equipment and factions. Again, there is no direct control over the ships during the battle. However, you can assign certain tasks and behaviors of your ships during the deployment phase.There is also an online mode of the game, which you can tackle space-craft formations created by other players.However, this sequel still fall short on one major problem inherited from the previous game. That is, the lack of a background story. Without a story-line to hold the game together, this game ultimately feels like a space battle simulator like the one in Ender’s Game.PresentationVisually speaking, the upgrade of graphics was not dramatic, but there are definitely more efforts put into the details of the space-crafts and the battlefield. Lighting and shadow effects were also improved to help create a more realistic 2.5 dimensional environment than its predecessor.Being able to build your dream ship is one thing, but the greatest enjoyment comes from the way it shines in action or…in total destruction.There was also a great improvement on the user interface during the battle and players can now look at each space-craft’s status at the same time. Although some of the icons might be a bit too large which could block the view of the battlefield, this was no doubt a welcoming improvement.SummaryIn summary, if you are interested in the previous game or being a Sci-Fi fan, there is no doubt that you will be spending hours and hours of time in this sequel. For those that are new, it depends on whether you would value the limitless creation provided by this game over the lack of a background story.

												GSB2 is a "more of the same" kind of sequel: where GSB1 had lots of races and three ship types, GSB2 has four races and six ship types.  The differences between each race and hull are more pronounced.I like this change, as I tended to only use one or two races in GSB1 and use the same hull for multiple roles.  The new ships come in three sizes, each with two classes and three hulls for that class.  Large ships, for example are cruisers and dreadnoughts; the former has a wider array of modules available but fewer slots, the latter has many slots but can only use heavy weeponry, so cannot defend itself against smaller ships or missiles.  The four races seem to have a bit more variety between them: hull bonuses have much larger magnitudes, making each one good for certain tasks - you no longer just pick the one with most sockets and ignore the rest.  This all adds more variety to the fleets you can field and allows your fleet to be more versatile.There are many small changes which make GSB2 quite different to play than it's predecessor...If you clump your ships together, they will arrange them selves into different layers (i.e. in 3D).  This prevents all that jostling which ruined your formations in GSB1.Weapons are also now resticted to arcs over which they can fire, according to their socket.  A dreadnough, for example, will have some front facing guns, some side-facing guns, and maybe one to the rear or a full 360° turret.  Cruisers will have more 360° turrets.The player can customise the appearance of their ships, helping to differentiate between roles (I paint all my long range ships blue, front line ships purple, defenders green etc.).Small ships (fighters and gunships) require a carrier bay in order to be deployed.  They have limited fuel and ammo and must return to said carrier to replenish these (if they survive).The campaign mode is different - you deploy a fleet and take it through a series of battles, only being able to re-deploy those ships which survived the last round.  It's rather short and easy, though.  I'd like to see more of these and higher difficulty added.You can now deploy two of your own fleets against each other, allowing you to test ship designs/deployments etc.There are still some improvements to be made, however...The flavour text is copy-pasted between modules of the same type, e.g. all the plasma guns have the same description.  It would be nice if they each got a description of what sets them appart from their neighbours.Shield boosting destroyers tend make front line dreadnoughts invincible.Fighter/Gunships are much too weak - they are deployer one-by-one from their carrier and move in an orderly queue as they fly into the wall of enemy flak.  These ships need to form a nasty swarm to be effective but they just don't carry enough fuel or ammo.I'd like to be able to zoom in on the visual customisation screen so I can place pieces more precisely.A few missions gave me loads of honour points and I gobbled up all the parts.  I then didn't feel like I had to optimise my fleet any more, I could just throw everything agains the single player missions.  I'd like to have some incentive to minimise my fleet, maybe having parts cost more honour; perhapse an expansion can add some very expensive (though not over powered) parts to buy.I'd still like more variation between races.  They all have 90% of the same stuff to use and will field variations on the same ships.  I'd like the races to feel wildly different, so you have to adjust your play style when playing both as and against them.I turned the voice-over off, it felt unncessary.  I don't need to be told I've entered ship design mode or that a ship is taking shield damage.  I can work these bits out for myself, I'm clever like that.I'd like to be able to tell the tutorial to bugger off.Over all, GSB2 still has what made GSB1 great.  There are some pros and cons but it feels like a worthy sequel.  However, I also feel you only get to make one "more of the same" sequel.  GSB3 had better be totally different.

												I loved the original GSB but the improvements made to GSB 2 are simply wonderful.  I have seen a few bugs but they are very minor and are not preventing me from enjoying the game. The explosions and destruction are quite satisfying. I do hope the races from the original GSB reappear in GSB 2 because I would love to work with the designs and tweak them.
